text: Joe we've tried to hit the party circles
circuit as best we can on this on this
week yesterday we saw mermaids at a
party of the aquarium that was quite a
sighting now we saw a little penguins
now but most of the parties here have
been by the super PACs the big parties
have been the financial interest have
had a lot of events can you tell us a
little about what you've seen last time
we talked here you were talking about
what you were expecting and money in
politics at this at this convention
that's true I think you know I've been
watching the role of money in politics
at Republican conventions going back to
nineteen eighty and I would say things
have gotten more secretive it's become a
more difficult beat to cover and I
couldn't even get press credentials
today for an event by one of the super
PACs called Americans for Prosperity
yeah didn't we have a reporter there
though we did but but not Jill Abramson
no now um do you think it's because of
your past history of writing about money
in politics so because you're the boss I
have no idea but they're keeping a very
tight lid on but the reporter from The
Times who was there did bring me an AFP
cookie from the event singapore symphony
yeah thank you very much thank you now
the other thing that we've we've talked
about a lot today really is the factual
questions the truth squatting of the
candidates are a lot of questions raised
in the media about what Paul Ryan said
last night and can you talk a little bit
about how we at the times try to track
that because it's in real time it's very
hard to keep up with who's saying what's
right and what's wrong you see it with
both Republicans and Democrats right
it's that's true it's it's difficult and
the Ryan speech came rather late in the
evening close to everyone everyone's
dead long newspaper deadline anyway but
I think it's one of the most important
roles news organizations have is to play
a very close attention to the words that
the candidates say and to analyze them
and in fact check them and something
that we did today that i thought was
marvelous as we did an interactive where
you could rewatch and here Paul Ryan
speech and then there was an annotation
on the side that went through at fact by
fact and pointed out that everything
from the GM factory that had been
shuttered before President Obama to the
office to cuts in Medicare to mr. Ryan's
criticism that President Obama simply
shelled the simpson-bowles commission's
report which he didn't point out he had
voted against it's a very cogent very
factual presentation of what was said
and what the facts are when we do this
fact checking in other news
organizations and also partisan sources
are continually looking at parsing what
the words are at the convention and then
ads and speeches do you think the din is
so loud that maybe certain partisans or
voters don't even care anymore and say
well I don't care what they say I want
Ryan or I don't want Ryan and that's it
I worry about that done I worried that
that the both campaigns and certainly at
this convention there's been a
risk/reward kind of thinking where the
risk of saying things that aren't
factual doesn't seem that gray that the
pace of the news cycle combine with
saying very strong aggressive thing
somehow supersedes sticking at least
close to the facts if not to the facts
themselves and I think that's
distressing for the tone of politics and
the health of the body politic when we
do fact checking the times and one party
or another seizes on what we do as
saying AHA the New York Times agrees
with us that
candidate a was wrong or inaccurate does
that make us risk looking partisan at
all well it's something that we have to
watch closely what we're doing is
showing what the and explaining what the
facts are in a non opinionated way and
if other people present what we've
reported to bolster an opinion it's it's
on them they're doing that it sometimes
concerns me but I think our highest duty
is to point out what the facts really
are in any situation that's what the new
york times news report is there to do
i'm hoping that after the speech tonight
after we've done all our fact-checking
that someone will let you into a good
party tonight say i'll try thanks a lot
Jill
